contentrichtext.text: {{Infobox Protected area | name = Watheroo National Park | iucn_category = II | photo = | photo_caption = | location = [[Mid West (Western Australia)|Mid West]] | nearest_city = [[Moora, Western Australia|Moora]] | lat_d = 30 | lat_m = 14 | lat_s = 24 | lat_NS = S | long_d = 115 | long_m = 52 | long_s = 43 | long_EW = E | map = Western Australia | map_width = 250 | region = AU-WA | area = {{convert|44481|ha|abbr=on}}<ref name="ParkAreas">{{cite journal| year=2010| title=Department of Environment and Conservation 2009â€“2010 Annual Report|pages=48|publisher = Department of Environment and Conservation| issn = 1835-114X| url = http://www.dec.wa.gov.au/content/view/6139/2345/}}</ref> | established = 1969 | visitation_num = | visitation_year = | governing_body = [[Department of Environment and Conservation (Western Australia)|Department of Environment and Conservation]] | url = http://www.dec.wa.gov.au/component/option,com_hotproperty/task,view/id,64/Itemid,755/ }} '''Watheroo National Park''' is a national park in [[Western Australia]] ([[Australia]]), 187 km north of [[Perth, Western Australia|Perth]]. It contains [[Jingemia Cave]]. The park is situated in the [[Mid West (Western Australia)|Mid West]] region of Western Australia to the west of the Midlands Road between the towns of [[Badgingarra, Western Australia|Badgingarra]] to the west and [[Dalwallinu, Western Australia|Dalwallinu]] to the east. The border of the park abuts Pinjarrega Nature Reserve to the north but is otherwise surrounded by farmland. Low Creek borders the park to the east which them flows south to join [[Moore River]]. The park is mostly composed of sand plain country which supports populations of [[heath]], [[Mallee (habit)|Mallee]] and [[Banksia]] and a large number of wildflowers. [[Eucalypt]] stands can be found to the western end of the park.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.dec.wa.gov.au/component/option,com_hotproperty/task,view/id,64/Itemid,755/|title=Department of Environment - Watheroo National Park|year=2007|accessdate=14 November 2010}}</ref> other species include the [[Triodia (plant genus)|spinifex]], [[wandoo]] and [[gum tree|yorm gum]]. Some of the wildflowers found within the park include [[Kwongan]], the [[Verticordia eriocephala|Bush Cauliflower]] and the [[Verticordia grandis|Scarlet featherflower]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.australiasgoldenoutback.com/en/Pages/Attraction.aspx?n=Watheroo_National_Park&pid=9001626|title=Australia's Golden Outback - Watheroo National Park|year=2009|accessdate=14 November 2010}}</ref> The name of the park comes from the [[Indigenous Australian]] name of a nearby [[Spring (hydrosphere)|spring]], it is also the name of a town located to the east of the park.<ref>{{LandInfo WA|c|W|15 November 2010}}</ref> Composed mostly of [[quartz]] based sand with outcrops of [[sandstone]] at times having a [[laterite]] cap the area acts as a basin basin between the Dandaragan plateau and the Darling plateau.<ref>{{cite AHD|10192|Watheroo National Park|date=1991|accessdate=16 September 2010}}</ref> In 2010, the [[Environmental Protection Authority of Western Australia|Environmental Protection Authority]] gave approval for to survey the Warro [[gas field]] that is located beneath the park. The company Latent Petroleum were given permission to conduct a [[seismic]] survey allowing them to drive over vegetation.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.abc.net.au/news/stories/2010/10/12/3036045.htm|title=''ABC News'' Park survey gets conditional approval|year=2010|accessdate=14 November 2010}}</ref> == References == {{reflist}} ==See also== * [[Protected areas of Western Australia]] {{National Parks of Western Australia}} [[Category:National parks of Western Australia]] [[Category:Protected areas established in 1969]] {{WesternAustralia-geo-stub}}
